results.content: Just what I was missing. I have worked with docker using Laravel and PHP for a long time and just wanted an idea for how docker-compose works with a MERN stack. After completing this course I can now successfully build MERN stacks and intend to build a mixed stack with a Laravel backend, React frontend, and Postgres DB soon.

results.content: The content is almost exactly what I was looking for in a course. The instructor does make a couple of mistakes but they are easily detectable and do not affect the overall outcome of the project. My biggest issue with the course is the video quality. The font size used and the video quality makes it hard to read.

response.content: Hi Praxent, so happy to hear you are enjoying the course and I’m very sad to hear about the difficult with the font size, I already asked Udemy to release the course on 1080p as that was the original resolution I sent to Udemy, they told me they are going to do it but I’ll contact that again to check on the hold up. Also I’ll make sure to increase the font size in the new classes and corses. Thank you again for call my attention to that.

results.content: In general, his presentation is too improvised for my taste. More importantly, it seems he is learning Docker as he is creating the class. For instance, his explanation of the Dockfile was Video 5 (time: 2:40) was not entirely accurate. And in Video 6 (time: 2:20) it is seems he doesn't understand the difference between an image and a container. Lastly, the videos need some additional editing, there are a couple places where he misspoke and then repeats himself. The most obvious is the clicker in Video 8 @ 0:34 and 5:48 which sounds like he slapped himself. :-)
results.content_html: In general, his presentation is too improvised for my taste. More importantly, it seems he is learning Docker as he is creating the class. For instance, his explanation of the Dockfile was Video 5 (time: 2:40) was not entirely accurate. And in Video 6 (time: 2:20) it is seems he doesn't understand the difference between an image and a container. Lastly, the videos need some additional editing, there are a couple places where he misspoke and then repeats himself. The most obvious is the clicker in Video 8 @ 0:34 and 5:48 which sounds like he slapped himself. :-)

results.content: I bought the Deno course from the same instructor where he uses Docker for the backend, frontend and database, was amazing make a course without have no install anything. I decide that I want to be able to do the same that is why I decide to do this course and I can say after watch it that I am. I never used docker before always think was a hype, now I want use everywhere.

response.content: Hi Arpit, I'm really sorry to hear that you didn't enjoy the course, remember this is not a beginners course, that is why basic concepts here not cover in detail. It seems that this course is a bit advanced for you I would recommend you to return it for a full refund, I would just ask that before you do that please rethink your review based on this new information I just pass to you, if you think that still valid from the point of an intermediate developer just leave as is, however, please reconsider remove it before you ask for a refund if the course was just a bit more advanced than you were expecting. Maybe was just a misunderstanding. Thank you.

results.content: The instructor makes many mistakes while writing the code. This and bcause it was often not clear what he really wanted to show made it very difficult for me to code along with him. Finally I gave up in the hope he would finally provide the github repository he initialized in one of the first videos. He promised to make it public at the end of the course but he apparently didn't intend to do so. Now I finished the course and if I wanted to have the fully functional project I would have to repeat most of the videos. As the whole course was very tedious I really don't want to listen another time to the whole sermon. Sorry for my honest rating.

response.content:
Hi Georg, thank you for our honest, the intention on the course was to show how it really is to develop a software, I could have edit out the mistakes, but in my humble opinion we learn making mistakes, I see over and over again people saying, I can solve this problem because I see it before, many people would have idea what to do if something go wrong, I use to get many question from people where they mistake was just a typo and they could not figure out the error. Since I decide to go for a “real life” approach I don’t see that happening anymore. 
About the content of the course, it is available at the SwiftNextStep GitHub repo. I’ll make the address more clear at the course. If you still cannot find please send me a message so I can help you. Again thank you for your review I’ll do my best to improve on your comments and I hope I can make the course better for you and the next person,

response.content: Hi Roel, I'm so sorry that was a terrible mistake on my side. During the course, someone calls my attention, and I start to increase the font size. However, Udemy also made this content available on 1080p, and please make sure to select that option for the best results. I'm trying to playing with video editing to make it better, but I cannot make any promises. Please remember that you can always return to the course with no hard feelings if you are not satisfied. I completely understand if you do. And if there is something you can't really understand, I'm always around to help. Thank you so much for your feedback
